issues.text: Whether the direction in the Sastry Award absolutely prohibited the Bank from transferring workmen not belonging to the subordinate staff outside the State or the language area without consent, or only required avoidance as far as possible

anchor.surface_text: Two contentions are urged before us in support of the appeal. The first is that the Labour Court erred in thinking that the direction in the Sastry Award absolutely prohibited the Bank from transferring workmen not belonging to the subordinate staff outside the State or the language area in which the employee had been serving except with his consent. On a proper construction, it was urged, the direction only required the bank to refrain from making such transfers as far as possible and did number prevent the bank from making such transfers where it was really found necessary in banks interests.

issues.text: Whether, given the bank's claim of acting in business interests and bona fide, the transfer contravened the direction in the Sastry Award

anchor.surface_text: The second contention was that when the bank claimed to have made the transfer in the interests of its business and was found to have acted bona fide, it should have been held that the direction in the Sastry Award had number been companytravened.

issues.text: Whether in the present case the appellant contravened the direction in the Sastry Award by transferring the respondent outside the Maharashtra State and language area

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to, the question whether in the present case the appellant companytravened the direction in the award in transferring the respondent outside the Maharashtra State in which he was serving and also outside the language area in which he had been serving.

arguments.claim: Transfer made in accordance with Sastry Award; no contravention justifying s.33A relief; appeal allowed, Labour Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the Labour Court has erred in holding that the transfer was not made in accordance with the standing orders regarding transfers as contained in the Sastry Award. W

holdings.text: The directions in the Sastry Award amounted to standing orders applicable to the bank's workmen within the meaning of s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that these directions were binding on the appellant-bank nor is it disputed before us that these directions amounted to standing orders applicable to Banks workmen within the meaning of s. 33 (2) of the Industrial Disputes Act. It cannot also be doubted that

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed by parties and affirmed by court as basis for analysis.

holdings.text: The transfer of the respondent resulted in a material alteration in his conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot also be doubted that the result of the transfer would be a material alteration in the respondents conditions of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court explicitly states it cannot be doubted, acknowledging change but assessing compliance.

holdings.text: The Sastry Award does not absolutely prohibit transfers of workmen not belonging to subordinate staff outside the State or language area without consent, but directs that such transfers be avoided as far as possible consistent with banking needs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is considerable force in both these contentions. It will be noticed that in making the directions as regards the transfer of workmen the Sastry Award drew a distinction between workmen belonging to the subordinate staff and others. As regards members of the subordinate staff the direction was to the effect that there should be no transfers ordinarily and there was absolute prohibition against transfers beyond the language area of the persons concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishing language for subordinate vs non-subordinate staff; deliberate use of 'as far as possible' indicates flexibility for business needs.

holdings.text: Industrial tribunals should ordinarily accept management's bona fide decision that a transfer was unavoidable for business interests, unless mala fide, victimization, unfair labour practice or ulterior motive is shown.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to, the question whether in the present case the appellant contravened the direction in the award in transferring the respondent outside the Maharashtra State in which he was serving and also outside the language area in which he had been serving. It is necessary to remember in this connection that a bank which has branches in different parts of the country has to distribute its total manpower between these different branches in accordance with the needs of these branches and with an eye to its business interests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management best placed to judge manpower distribution; tribunals lack materials and suitability for such decisions; policy to preserve banking efficiency.

holdings.text: The Labour Court's finding rejecting the respondent's allegations of mala fides, victimization or unfair labour practice is correct; no evidence supports such claims.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Labour Court has rejected the respondents challenge to the bona fides of the management. It has held that there is no evidence whatever to support the complainants allegation that he was transferred because he joined the Union and that the management had adopted a particular policy towards the workmen of the Union. We can find nothing that would justify us in interfering with the Labour Courts finding that these allegations have not been proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence; no basis to interfere with Labour Court's credibility assessment; transfer harsh but not unfair.

holdings.text: The appellant did not contravene the direction in the Sastry Award by transferring the respondent to Trichur.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the Labour Court has erred in holding that the transfer was not made in accordance with the standing orders regarding transfers as contained in the Sastry Award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compliant with 'as far as possible' given bona fides and business needs; no prohibited grounds present.

holdings.text: There was no contravention of s.33 of the Industrial Disputes Act warranting relief under s.33A; the appeal is allowed and the Labour Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court and order that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No change contrary to standing orders; application fails for lack of contravention.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 interprets the Sastry Award direction on transfers, directly addressing issue i1 on whether it absolutely prohibited such transfers.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is considerable force in both these contentions. It will be noticed that in making the directions as regards the transfer of workmen the Sastry Award drew a distinction between workmen belonging to the subordinate staff and others. As regards members of the subordinate staff the direction was to the effect that there should be no transfers ordinarily and there was absolute prohibition against transfers beyond the language area of the persons concerned.

edges.explanation: h3 interprets Sastry Award directions on transfers in context of business needs, addressing i2's question on contravention given business interests

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to, the question whether in the present case the appellant contravened the direction in the award in transferring the respondent outside the Maharashtra State in which he was serving and also outside the language area in which he had been serving. It is necessary to remember in this connection that a bank which has branches in different parts of the country has to distribute its total manpower between these different branches in accordance with the needs of these branches and with an eye to its business interests.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court and order that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Labour Court has rejected the respondents challenge to the bona fides of the management. It has held that there is no evidence whatever to support the complainants allegation that he was transferred because he joined the Union and that the management had adopted a particular policy towards the workmen of the Union. We can find nothing that would justify us in interfering with the Labour Courts finding that these allegations have not been proved.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court and order that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the Labour Court has erred in holding that the transfer was not made in accordance with the standing orders regarding transfers as contained in the Sastry Award.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court and order that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court and order that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.
